Big Data is what will lead to greater power plant (both large and small, so everything from nuclear reactors to car engines) efficiencies as well as better monitoring of the health of infrastructure, by having a far granular dataset to better predict or react to conditions, such as increased temperatures in one region of the country may require more power produced, while also denoting that a road may need to be patched due to that increase in temperature. Big data will also lead to better economic models, as well as finding correlation in disparate systems, such as the rise in demand for chocolate chip cookies after a particular sports team loses. Big Data will lead to not only better artificial intelligence, but also think of how it would enable self-healing systems. There are so many applications for data collection and analysis.Moore’s Law, the observation that the number of components in an integrated circuit doubles roughly every year to 18 months, has driven semiconductor development, and in turn helped drive software production. Imagine wanting to write a program to do a really cool thing, but the cost of the computer to run your program costs $3,000. If you’re concerned that no one will buy it because the costs are high today, this would put a damper on development. However, if you think that it will take you 4.5 years to develop, the price of the components necessary to run your program would have dropped dramatically, placing an expensive computer that you used as a target for your application to drop in price, thus making your application more financially feasible.Moore’s Law has also affected the price, availability, and capability of sensors at an exponential rate, too. As the price of sensors continues to drop, and the forward progress of cellular technology brings down the price of slower technologies as new ones come online, data collection not only becomes far easier, it also gets exponentially cheaper. When 5G cellular technology rolls out over the next couple of years, 4G/4G LTE will drop in price and become the standard that the IoT will use for communications. Moore’s Law will probably also be used as the baseline for IoT adoption, so you can imagine how quickly sensors and automated systems will be deployed.While we have made tremendous gains in the Information Age, we are still only scratching the surface, and new applications for computer systems are coming every day.
